comment._content: Gifford Pinchot (PIN-sho) pioneering conservationist, was the first chief of the U. S. Forest Service, and the 28th Govenor of Pennsylvania. He first checked into the Battle Creek Sanitarium in January, 1911. Prohibitionist and Vegetarian Dr. John Harvey Kellogg, a Seventh-Day Adventist, was the eccentric dictator of the Battle Creek Sanitarium. (His brother, Will K. Kellogg, started the Kellogg's cereal company -- beginning with corn flakes -- as an offshoot of the Sanitarium's work in developing health foods. C. W. Post, a patient at the "San," also liked the bland diet there, and became the multi-millionaire owner of the Post Cereals Company.) Samuel Sidney McClure (1857-1949) was the founder of the McClure Newspaper Syndicate and editor-publisher of McClure's Magazine, a muckraking organ of the Progressive movement, from 1893 to 1911. Through his magazine, McClure boosted recognition and acceptance of the early-childhood educational theories of Maria Montessori. "He is a firm believer in the value of the low-protein diet, which he claims has doubled his ability for work and quadrupled his endurance. . . ." Iriving Fisher (1867-1947) was an American economist, health reformer, and eugenicist. When he contracted TB, he "took the cure" at the Battle Creek Sanitarium, and afterwards became a health reformer himself. He introduced the practice of calorie counting as part of a diet regimen. He was also a Prohibitionist: Prohibition of alcohol was a major tenet of the Seventh Day Adventists and of Dr. Kellogg's Sanitarium. Sir H. Plunkett, Irish Unionist, had been for twenty years the Minister for Agriculture for Ireland. In Ireland, he promoted the ideals of the Battle Creek Sanitarium: books.google.com/books?id=5KnhAAAAMAAJ&pg=PA16&dq... This photo appears to have been taken in the sunny conservatory (Palm Garden) of the Battle Creek Sanitarium. The building's exterior, in another Bain/LOC photo: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/library_of_congress/4647156705/] Dr. John Harvey Kellogg, impresario of the "San": [http://www.flickr.com/photos/library_of_congress/4647770910/in/photostream/]

comment._content: Pinchot's papers are at the Library of Congress. Included is a daily diary, so it is probably possible to determine the date and place this photo was taken. Pinchot mentions Plunkett and McClure in his autobiography, Breaking New Ground.

comment.author: 70251312@N00
comment._content: It's too bad that Horace Fletcher isn't in this photo -- he was an even odder food faddist than this bunch. Fletcher's book, "Fletcherism," defined proper mastication of food as chewing every bite thirty-two times before swallowing -- once for each tooth. The process became known as "Fletcherizing," and the word "Fletcherize" entered the dictionaries (at least briefly).

comment.author: 70251312@N00
comment._content:
"Pinchot . . . long suffered from problems of the eye, skin and digestive system. In January 1911 he enrolled in the John Harvey Kellogg Sanitarium in Battle Creek, Michigan. The notion of preventive medicine -- staying well rather than getting cured -- was innovative, and the high-mindedness of Kellogg's program, which centered on obedience to natural law as a moral duty, obviously appealed to Pinchot. Kellogg's ban on alcohol and tobacco would not have been a problem, but Pinchot had a sweet tooth and probably thought twice about the restriction on chocolate."
--intro to The Conservation Diaries of Gifford Pinchot, edited by Harold K. Steen

comment.author: 70251312@N00
comment._content: As noted above, this photo probably dates from 1911. The likely occasion for Bain circulating it to his subscribers in 1913 was a banquet of repeat visitors to the Battle Creek Sanitarium, held at the "San" on October 28, 1913. The highly-enthusiastic Sir Horace Plunkett, of Dublin, Ireland, was among those in attendance on that day: Story from "The Battle Creek Idea," November, 15, 1913: books.google.com/books?id=5KnhAAAAMAAJ&pg=PA259&l...; Sanitarium Banquet&f=false
